docs.lead_paragraph: In a push to lock down votes, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Finance Committee, is pulling together changes to his health care bill intended to address the chief concern among Democrats: that health insurance be made as affordable as possible for moderate-income Americans. Among the proposals under consideration is an amendment by Senator Maria Cantwell, Democrat of Washington, that would create a ''basic health plan'' for Americans earning less than 200 percent of the federal poverty level, or $44,100 for a family of four. The proposal would let states develop or expand various existing insurance programs that now typically cover people who qualify for Medicaid. Small states could develop joint plans.
docs.abstract: Sen Max Baucus, chairman of Finance Committee, is pulling together changes to his health care bill in effort to address Democrats' concern that health insurance be made as affordable as possible for moderate-income Americans; proposals under consideration include amendment that would create basic health plan for Americans earning less than 200 percent of federal poverty level (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Liberal opposition to Senators Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Finance Committee, and Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, has intensified since the two voted against a government-run insurance plan, or public option, on Tuesday. Two groups, Progressive Change Campaign Committee and Democracy for America, vowed to raise money and run advertisements against the two senators in hopes of pressuring them to vote for a public option when the legislation reaches the Senate floor, which could be as early as the week after next.
docs.abstract: Liberal opposition to Senators Max Baucus and Olympic Snowe has intensified since they voted against government-run health insurance plan known as public option; Progressive Change Campaign Committee and Democracy for America have vowed to raise money and run advertisements against Baucus and Snowe in hope of pressuring them to vote for public option; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: All the versions of health care bills now in Congress would require all but the smallest employers to provide health care coverage or pay into a government pool to help provide coverage for the otherwise uninsured. Critics predict that many businesses would simply drop health benefits because it would be cheaper to pay the new tax. The steepest of the proposed penalties, one under consideration in the House, would assess most businesses a tax of 8 percent of payroll. The cost of providing employee health insurance is typically 12 percent of payroll, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
docs.abstract: All versions of health care bills now in Congress would require all but smallest employers to provide health care coverage or pay into government pool to help provide coverage for people otherwise uninsured; critics predict that many businesses would simply drop health benefits because it would be cheaper to pay new tax (S)

byline.original: By ROBB MANDELBAUM, from the You're the Boss blog

docs.lead_paragraph: The recession is driving up enrollment in Medicaid at higher-than-expected rates, threatening gargantuan state budget gaps even as Congress and the White House seek to expand the program, according to a survey released Wednesday. The annual survey of state Medicaid directors, conducted for the Kaiser Family Foundation's Commission on Medicaid and the Uninsured, found that the program, which insures the poor and the disabled, had been spared the worst effects of huge state budget shortfalls because of federal aid in the stimulus package. But it also revealed grave concerns about what will happen when that relief dries up at the close of 2010.

headline.main: Medicaid Enrollment Soars, and State Directors See a Threat

docs.abstract: Annual survey of state Medicaid directors finds that recession is driving up Medicaid enrollment at higher-than-expected rates, posing threat of huge state budget gaps; finds that enrollment grew by average of 5.4% in fiscal 2009, highest rate in six years; projects growth of 6.6% in fiscal 2010; chart (M)
